metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-eddy covariance system-40m tower, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Huailai station eddy covariance system (EC) from January 1 to October 24 in 2019. The site (115.7923° E, 40.3574°N) was located in the maize surface, near Donghuayuan town of Huailai city in Hebei Province. The elevation is 480 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&EC150) was 0 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), which represent high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. There were lots of negative values of H2O density in winter where filling by -6999.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Guo et al. (2020) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2013) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method for measuring aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces is the use of wind profile measurements based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. This approach was utilized in the Xiaotangshan Experiment, where z0m over each surface component was calculated with characteristic parameters of roughness elements such as vegetation height and leaf area index, and then aggregated using the footprint weighting method.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using large aperture scintillometers (LAS) for surface flux measurements?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in using LAS for surface flux measurements is the difficulty in converging the iteration process under low wind speed and very stable conditions at night. This problem is compounded by the sensitivity of sensible heat flux (HLAS) to factors such as beam height, wind speed, and zero-plane displacement height.

Example.Question: How does the process of data quality evaluation in surface flux observations illustrate methodological rigor?
Example.Answer: The process of data quality evaluation in surface flux observations illustrates methodological rigor through several steps, including wild point value elimination, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality assessment of flux values involves checking atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity characteristics, with classification into three quality levels based on set thresholds.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key data collection challenges when using large aperture scintillometers for surface flux measurements?
Feature Specification.Answer: sensitivity to beam height and wind speed, need for accurate Bowen ratio determination over wet surfaces, difficulties in universal stability function convergence under low wind speeds and stable night conditions

Feature Specification.Question: What are the factors that influence the aggregation of aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'eddy covariance' in the context of surface flux measurement?
Definition.Answer: Eddy covariance is a data collection method used to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the Earth's atmosphere. It involves using instruments like sonic anemometers and gas analyzers to measure the fluctuations of wind velocity and trace gas concentrations, such as CO2 and H2O, at high frequencies (e.g., 10Hz). The method allows for direct observation of exchanges of energy, gases, and momentum between the surface and the atmosphere over time and is key in understanding surface-atmosphere interactions.

Definition.Question: How is 'aerodynamic roughness length (z0m)' defined and why is it important in surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is defined as the height where the wind speed, extrapolated from the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. It is a crucial factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and land surface models, as it describes the roughness characteristics of a surface. The variation of z0m is large over different surfaces, influencing wind turbulence and consequently the calculation of surface fluxes.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with using the Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in using the Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements include determining the form of the universal stability function and achieving convergence in the iteration process under low wind speed and stable conditions, particularly at night. Factors such as the beam height of LAS and wind speed sensitivity, zero-plane displacement height, and accurate determination of the Bowen ratio over wet surfaces are crucial for accurate sensible heat flux measurement.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection frequencies and temporal resolutions between the eddy covariance system and the large aperture scintillometer?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance system collects data at a high frequency of 10 Hz, processed into 30-minute average values, whereas large aperture scintillometer data typically cover larger spatial scales and might not have such high temporal resolution, focusing instead on daily and monthly variations and larger spatial footprint measurements.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the methods of estimating aerodynamic roughness length differ when using eddy covariance data versus remote sensing models?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance data typically estimate aerodynamic roughness length based on wind profile measurements and Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, adjusted for surface characteristics. Remote sensing models, however, often rely on parameterizations derived from land surface properties such as vegetation height and leaf area index, which can be more challenging to apply accurately at local or regional scales without direct station observations.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the influence of roughness element characteristics on aerodynamic roughness length from the data collected at various surfaces?
Interpretation.Answer: The inference is that the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is influenced by roughness element characteristics such as vegetation height and leaf area index, as these elements control wind turbulence. This relationship can be parameterized to aid in model applications, indicating that z0m varies directionally due to the heterogeneity of roughness elements across different surfaces.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data processing steps, such as coordinate rotation and density correction, affect the quality and reliability of surface flux measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: The data processing steps, including coordinate rotation and density (WPL) correction, are crucial for ensuring the quality and reliability of surface flux measurements. These steps help in correcting raw data for anomalies and errors, thereby providing more accurate values for flux measurements and ensuring stability and similarity in atmospheric conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What potential challenges can arise in measuring surface fluxes over heterogeneous surfaces, and how might these be addressed through data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in measuring surface fluxes over heterogeneous surfaces include dealing with variability in roughness element size and distribution, which affects the aerodynamic roughness length. Addressing these challenges may involve using footprint models to account for directional dependencies and employing parameterizations that relate surface properties to roughness length for more accurate estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a significant variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different land surfaces, and how does it impact remote sensing models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces is primarily due to the heterogeneity in the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements, such as vegetation and terrain, which affect wind turbulence. This variation impacts remote sensing models because z0m is a critical parameter in estimating surface fluxes, influencing the accuracy of these models in representing surface-atmosphere interactions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining accurate z0m values for local or regional scales based on station observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in obtaining accurate z0m values for local or regional scales are due to the difficulty in capturing the spatial variability of surface roughness with limited station observations. The complexity of land surface characteristics and the influence of diverse roughness elements make it challenging to generalize z0m values from localized measurements to broader areas, necessitating parameterization approaches that incorporate land surface properties like vegetation height and leaf area index.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using Eddypro software for post-processing 10Hz data to obtain 30-minute averages in atmospheric flux measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using Eddypro software involves several post-processing steps such as outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and WPL correction, which result in more accurate and reliable 30-minute averaged flux measurements. This process also includes quality assessments of flux values, which help ensure the integrity of the data by identifying and excluding erroneous data, such as those affected by instrument errors or weak turbulence at night.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the exclusion of data during precipitation events and post-precipitation periods impact the accuracy and reliability of flux measurements in surface flux datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding data during and shortly after precipitation events helps maintain the accuracy and reliability of flux measurements by removing data that might be affected by wet sensors or altered surface conditions, which can introduce errors in measurement. These exclusions are necessary to ensure the data reflects normal atmospheric conditions and to prevent the effects of precipitation from distorting flux measurements.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to parameterize aerodynamic roughness length in land surface models and remote sensing algorithms?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Parameterizing aerodynamic roughness length is crucial for accurately modeling and estimating surface fluxes, as it accounts for the roughness characteristics of a surface which affect wind turbulence and energy exchanges, especially in heterogeneous landscapes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind comparing large aperture scintillometer data with eddy covariance system observations for surface flux measurements?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include analyzing the daily and monthly variations in sensible heat flux measurements, understanding the differences and complementarities between the two methods, and addressing issues like energy balance closure and footprint model applicability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) be estimated over heterogeneous surfaces, and what methodological considerations are necessary?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Estimating z0m over heterogeneous surfaces involves calculating z0m for each surface component by considering characteristic parameters like vegetation height and leaf area index. The z0m for the entire experimental field is then aggregated using a footprint weighting method. The directional dependence of z0m due to the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements must be considered to ensure accurate parameterization.

Enablement.Question: How do experimental setups in heterogeneous environments enhance the understanding of aerodynamic roughness length variations across different surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Experimental setups in heterogeneous environments, such as the Xiaotangshan Experiment, utilize analytical footprint models to calculate and analyze the directional characteristics of aerodynamic roughness length over various surface components. This approach allows the aggregation of roughness length over the entire field using footprint weighting methods, offering insights into the influence of roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index.

Enablement.Question: What factors enable the use of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) for measuring surface fluxes over larger scales compared to traditional methods?
Enablement.Answer: The use of LAS is enabled by its ability to measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km) compared to traditional methods. Factors such as beam height of LAS and wind speed are crucial for accurately measuring sensible heat flux, and understanding these parameters allows for effective use of LAS over both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for discrepancies between eddy covariance system and large aperture scintillometer observations?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies between eddy covariance system and large aperture scintillometer observations could arise from differences in the measurement scales, as scintillometers measure over larger areas. Additionally, factors like the beam height of the scintillometer, wind speed sensitivity, and issues with energy balance and footprint models could contribute to these observation differences.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring the accuracy of data collected from eddy covariance systems, particularly in seasonal changes or varying weather conditions?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential challenges in ensuring accuracy include addressing data gaps during equipment malfunctions, such as the power supply issues noted in August, and handling data inaccuracies caused by environmental factors, like negative water vapor density readings in winter. Additionally, the removal of data due to rainfall and low turbulence conditions suggests that seasonal changes and varying weather conditions can significantly impact data reliability.

Judgmental.Question: How might the integration of aerodynamic roughness length calculations enhance the precision of land surface flux estimations in remote sensing models?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of aerodynamic roughness length calculations could enhance precision by offering parameterizations that account for the heterogeneity and direction-dependence of surface roughness elements. This approach could provide a more refined input for remote sensing models, improving the estimation of surface fluxes over diverse land covers.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could large aperture scintillometer (LAS) measurements complement eddy covariance systems in data collection, considering their respective sensitivities and observational scales?
Judgmental.Answer: LAS measurements could complement eddy covariance systems by providing surface flux data over larger spatial scales, which might be beneficial in heterogeneous landscapes. Given that LAS is sensitive to factors like beam height and wind speed, it could offer a different observational perspective, potentially balancing the localized measurements of eddy covariance systems and addressing energy unbalance issues.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how the observation data from eddy covariance systems are processed to ensure accuracy and reliability.
Assertion.Answer: The observation data from eddy covariance systems are processed using Eddypro software, which includes steps like outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is performed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how aerodynamic roughness length is estimated for different land surfaces, especially in heterogeneous environments.
Assertion.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length is estimated using an analytical footprint model to calculate it over different surfaces. This involves using characteristic parameters of roughness elements such as vegetation height and leaf area index, and then aggregating the roughness length over the entire experimental field using the footprint weighting method.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why large aperture scintillometers are not commonly used for surface flux measurements in China.
Assertion.Answer: Large aperture scintillometers (LAS) have become more popular for measuring surface fluxes on larger scales, but in China, their observation is not common. Despite their capability to measure surface fluxes over both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces, challenges such as determining the Bowen ratio accurately over wet surfaces and sensitivity to factors like beam height and wind speed may contribute to limited use.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a research approach that utilizes large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data for measuring surface fluxes, and discuss factors influencing the accuracy of these measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: A research approach using LAS data for surface flux measurements involves analyzing the daily and monthly variations of sensible heat flux (H). Factors influencing the accuracy include beam height, wind speed, zero-plane displacement height, and Bowen ratio, which must be determined accurately over wet surfaces. The approach can involve comparing LAS measurements with those from an eddy covariance system and using footprint models to account for energy imbalance. LAS can effectively measure fluxes over both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces, but challenges remain in determining the universal stability function and ensuring convergence under low wind speed and stable conditions.
